title: 3rd arrest made in case of toddler hit by broom handle at Phoenix day-care facility

355 CONNECT TWEET LINKEDIN 3 COMMENT EMAIL MORE Phoenix police arrested a south Phoenix day-care's owner, director and an employee after a 21-month-old boy was struck twice by a broom handle, suffering a 4-inch cut on his face, according to police and court documents.
Lillie Adams, 37, was taken into custody on suspicion of child abuse, after police said they saw video from day-care cameras showing Adams hitting the boy on Feb. 17.
Police also arrested the owner of the Brighter Angels Learning Center, Ruben Sandoval, 51, and its director, Perla Denise Sierra Duarte, 26, in connection with allegations of hindering prosecution and failure to report the crime, according to Sgt. Mercedes Fortune, a Phoenix police spokeswoman.
The child was taken to Phoenix Children's Hospital by his mother, court documents said.
Ruben Sandoval   (Photo: Maricopa County Sheriff's Office) 
Perla Denise Sierra Duarte   (Photo: Maricopa County Sheriff's Office) 
The boy's mother returned to the day care after taking her son for treatment and asked to see video of the room at the time of the accident. She was told she could not see the video. According to court documents released Friday, the day-care director gave the mother a letter from the school stating that the child had "tripped over a toy and bumped his head on a table."
The day-care director, Duarte, also told Adams to sign a resignation later and "not to talk to anyone about this, including the police," according to court documents.
Officers were called to the day care on 7227 S. Central Ave. at about 8:20 a.m. Feb. 17 to investigate the report of an injured child, police said.
According to Adams, she was cleaning up cereal that a group of 1- to 2-year-olds who were in the play area had spilled. Adams told officers the boy had crawled under a table where she was sweeping, and she asked him to move twice.
When he wouldn't move, Adams hit him, but told police "she did not believe she hit him that hard," court documents said.
Adams was booked on suspicion of one count of reckless child abuse, a Class 3 felony. She was released on her own recognizance. Her next court appearance was scheduled for March 9.
